_header: Lo here two kings right perfect and right good
Note: A variant text in Fabyan, Robert , New Chronicles of Englande and of Fraunce, Pynson, 1533 ; Cf. 6322. See also 3841.
Subjects: occasional verse; Henry VI, coronation; pageant verses; chronicles, verse in; epilogues
_description: The ‘Sotelties’ at the Coronation Banquet of Henry VI (1432), by Lydgate — three 8-line stanzas, each preceded by the menu for the accompanying course

OxfStJohn57.Transcription:
lo here too kyngis riȝte perfite & riȝte goodHoly
                    seyntis Edward and seynt lowisAnd se the braunche born of hir blessid
                    bloodlyue a mong cristen most soveren of priseheriter of the floure
                    deliseGod graunte he may þurh help of criste IhesuThis sixt herry
                    regne & be as wiseAnd hem resembill in knyȝthode and
                    vertu
OxfStJohn57.Note:
Inserted in prose chronicle which begins with the year 1440, ff.
                    138-223.
OxfStJohn57.Editions:
Hammond,  Eleanor Prescott. 
             “Two Tapestry Poems by Lydgate: the Life of St. George and the Falls of
                Seven Princes.” 
             Englische Studie
         43 (1910-11): 10-26: 23.

BLAdd6113.First Lines: Loo here here be two kingis kingis right profitable & right goodholy saint Edwarde and saint Lewis also…
BLAdd6113.Last Lines: …The vith henry to Reigne & be as wiseand him to resemble in knighthode & vertue
BLAdd6113.Note: Written as prose, in prose description.

BLCottJulBI.First Lines:
Loo here twoo kyngis right perfite and right goodHoly Seint Edwarde
                    and Seint lowes…
BLCottJulBI.Last Lines:
…This sixt henry to reign and be as wiseAnd hem resemble in
                    knyghthod & vertue
BLCottJulBI.Editions:
Nicolas,  Nicholas Harris,  and  Edward Tyrrell, eds.  
             A Chronicle of London, from 1079 to 1483.
         London: Longman, 1827: 168-9.
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS
         o.s. 192 (1934); repr. 1961: 623-4.
Harvey,  John Harper. 
             Gothic England: A Survey of National Culture, 1300-1550.
         New York: Scribner, 1947: 179-80.

BLLan285.First Lines:
Lo here two kynges right parfite and right goodehooly seynte
                    Edwarde and seynt Lowes…
BLLan285.Last Lines:
…Borne by discent and title of RightIustely to Reigne in
                    Englond and ffraunce

Guildhall3313.First Lines:
Lo here two kynges right parfite and right goodHoly seyntes Edwarde
                    and seint Lowes…
Guildhall3313.Last Lines:
…Bore by discente and by title of rightIustely to regne in
                    Englond and in ffraunce
Guildhall3313.Note:
First line written as part of introductory heading rather than in verse
                    lines with the rest.
Guildhall3313.Attributed Title:
A sotilte Seynt Edwarde and seint Lowes armed in Cote Armures bryngyng yn
                    betwene hem in his Coote of armes with this scripture (f.
                    129v)
Guildhall3313.Editions:
Thomas,  Arthur Hermann,  and  Isobel Dorothy Thornley, eds.  
             The Great Chronicle of London…Attributed to Robert
                Fabyan.
         London: G. W. Jones, 1938: 152-3.
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 98.

BLEge1995.First Lines:
Loo here ben ii kyngys ryght profytabylle and ryght goodeholy Synt
                    Edwarde and synt lowys…
BLEge1995.Last Lines:
…the vi harry To raygne and be as wyseAnd hym resemble in
                    kynghode and vertu. Amen
BLEge1995.Editions:
Gairdner,  James,
                        ed.  
             Historical Collections of a Citizen of London.
Camden Society
         n.s. 17 (1876): 169-70.

PierpontM775.First Lines:
Lo here two kynges right perfit & right goodHoly seynt Edwarde
                    and allso seynt lowes…
PierpontM775.Last Lines:
…This sixte herry to regne and be as wiseAnd resemble in
                    knyghthode and vertu
PierpontM775.Note:
With heading, ‘The blades of the same’ (f. 15); written to
                    accompany the first course on the day of the coronation of Henry
                    VI.
PierpontM775.Editions:
Arthur,  H.,
                                viscount Dillon 
             “On a Manuscript Collection of Ordinances of Chivalry.” 
             Archaeologia
         57 (1900-01): 29-70: 57-8.
